Resources for Parolees We’re updating resources for people with humanitarian parole in multiple languages every other week.
text:
This is a monthly newsletter about humanitarian parole and policy changes impacting people who entered the United States on parole and their supporters. The newsletter includes updates on policy, litigation, and Congressional activity impacting parole, tells stories about people on parole and their communities, and shares resources and explainers. It is part of a campaign to oppose attacks on parole and immigration enforcement efforts against parolees because they imperil people in need of safety and deprive American cities and towns of beloved and valuable community members.

→ Join our WhatsApp Channel sharing critical information and updates for people with humanitarian parole and encourage your network to subscribe using this link.

→ Click here to access our Congressional take action and social media toolkit to Let Them Stay.

Latest on Litigation

Doe v. Noem is a case challenging the mass termination of the Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, Venezuela (CHNV) parole processes and thehalting of adjudications of immigration applications for parolees who entered on CHNV and other parole programs including Uniting for Ukraine (U4U) and family reunification parole.

Here’s where we are:

On September 12, the First Circuit Court of Appealsheld that the administration’s early mass termination of CHNV parole was likely lawful. In its opinion, the court interpreted that the language of the parole statute and its legislative history do not require parole to be terminated on an individualized basis. The court did not think Secretary Noem needed to further consider the “urgent humanitarian reasons” motivating the CHNV program – and their continued relevance for CHNV beneficiaries. However, the court did recognize:

“the risks of irreparable harm [that mass termination has wrought]… that parolees who lawfully arrived in this country were suddenly forced to choose between leaving in less than a month – a choice that potentially includes being separated from their families, communities, and lawful employment and returning to dangers in their home countries… or staying after the loss of their legal status, which means the risk of removal proceedings and detention, the loss of any work authorization, and potential effects on their eligibility for other forms of immigration relief in the future.”

The September 12 decision means termination of parole and work authorization remains in effect for CHNV beneficiaries while litigation over the lawfulness of the CHNV parole termination continues at the district court. The September 12 decision does not affect the district court’s May 28, 2025, order, which requires the government to process the immigration benefits applications – including for asylum and green cards – for humanitarian parole beneficiaries.

CHIRLA v. Noem is a case challenging the administration’s placement of people who entered through parole into expedited removal, a fast-track deportation process.

Here’s where we are:

On September 12, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit denied the government’s request to stay the district court’s order to protect people paroled into the United States from expedited removal. This ruling leaves in place the district court’s order, issued on August 1, which found that it was unlawful to place those who entered on humanitarian parole into expedited removal. This means that any person who entered on parole and is detained should insist that ICE cannot place them in expedited removal per the lower court’s decision. Please contact Hilary Li at JAC, if you hear of cases of ICE nonetheless pursuing expedited removal.

Latest on Enforcement Policies

Dismissals of cases and arrests by ICE at immigration courts have dropped off significantly (and these practices are being challenged in federal court in New York.) But, on September 8, the Supreme Court ruled that immigration agents can stop, question, and demand papers from anyone they guess to be here illegally based on how they look, what language they speak, what work they do, or where they happen to be. This sanctions the ongoing violent, racialized immigration enforcement by masked agents in Massachusetts, Los Angeles, Washington DC, and Chicago that has led to arrests of, among others, people who arrived on parole and are seeking asylum and who are legal permanent residents and U.S. citizens. Communities have mobilized to protect their neighbors, including through alerts about the presence of immigration enforcement and through protests – in Washington DC, in upstate New York, and near the Midway Airport outside Chicago – to stop arrests. Congregations and communities are coming together to support families impacted by immigration arrests and organizing protests at ICE detention facilities.

The administration’s effort to turn USCIS into an agency that hinders application processing and handles immigration enforcement is happening on many fronts, including:

USCIS hampered the ability of Venezuelans to take advantage of a court order reinstating their TPS by making it impossible to re-register electronically through the USCIS website – a problem that was only fixed by bringing additional litigation.

A regulation giving USCIS officers not only the power to issue orders of expedited removal but to carry weapons and make arrests – including potentially arresting sponsors or supporters accompanying relatives to interviews and appointments – will go into effect on October 6.

Forthcoming proposed regulations will limit eligibility for work authorization. This will come on top of the already lengthening adjudication times for work authorization applications, partly caused by USCIS’s eliminating efficiencies and adding dilatory and unnecessary vetting to their procedures.

These changes at USCIS have had, and will have, important impacts on people who entered on parole. Though USCIS has been ordered to resume processing applications by parolees per the Doe v. Noem lawsuit, attorneys in that case have complained of lack of “meaningful action” on diversity visa applications. USCIS has told E-verify employers to check status reports that list revoked work permits, though some people who entered on humanitarian parole may be eligible to work based on other applications.

People who have come in on parole should be aware of resources such as the Legal Pathways Learning Tool and others that may help them find alternative authority to work. A legal challenge – Sileiri Doe v. Noem – to the mass termination of parole and revocation of work permits for people who arrived through CBP One appointments is ongoing.

Latest from Congress

On September 18, the Congresswoman Jayapal of the House Subcommittee on Immigration Integrity, Security, and Enforcement (House Judiciary Committee) hosted a shadow hearing titled “Kidnapped and Disappeared: Trump’s Assault Destroys U.S. Families and Communities.” Members highlighted how they have had to navigate information blackouts, instances when they have not been able to locate constituents across ICE detention facilities, the shortage of publicly available data, and limited responses from the administration.

The hearing featured witnesses who testified about the traumatic arrest, detention, and deportation of loved ones and underscored the damage wrought on American communities and the economy by the Trump administration’s immigration enforcement policies. Witnesses also proposed solutions including the creation of legal pathways to citizenship, greater transparency to challenge indiscriminate enforcement practices, and amplifying constituents’ stories to help shape public understanding of the issue.

FY26 Appropriations Update: The House GOP leadership released bill text for a continuing resolution to keep the government open through November 21. Separately, Democrats released bill text for a proposal of their own to keep the government open through October 31. At the time of writing, Speaker Johnson is eyeing a vote on the GOP CR by September 19, and if passed, would then move to the Senate where Democrats have already come out in strong opposition to a stopgap bill. Relatedly, while the House had already released its Homeland Security funding bill and approved out of committee on June 24, the Senate is yet to release its version.

Resources for Parolees

We’re updating resources for people with humanitarian parole in multiple languages every other week.

Need this resource in another language? Or is there another language you can help translate this resource into? Contact Yael Schacher yschacher@refugeesinternational.org.

Story Spotlight:

“It immediately felt like family, like we were lifelong friends.”

Sandra McAnany is a 58-year-old grandmother from Wisconsin who welcomed and supported 17 people—11 adults and six children through the CHNV humanitarian parole program. Sandra is one of the plaintiffs in the Doe v. Noem lawsuit to Let Them Stay.

“We don’t know what the future is… but I want to be optimistic and hopeful that every person I sponsored will be able to stay here safely in the U.S. and continue to thrive.”Read more on Sandra’s story in Upworthy.Read more on Sandra’s story in Upworthy.

In the Media:

Dayton Daily News: Dayton Area Churches lament immigrant families negatively affected by new policies

Milwaukee Journal Sentinel: My Wisconsin manufacturing plant needs workers. One of our best is getting deported.

Cardinal News: Violence at home in Haiti and the promise of a good job brought them to Danville. They don’t know where they’ll go now.

Investigate West: Ukrainian immigrants becoming collateral damage in Trump administration’s immigration war

Reuters: Court rejects challenge to Trump ending thousands of migrants’ legal status

New York Times: Trump’s Reversals on Immigration Mount Over Economic Concerns

The Guardian: Los Angeles on edge as agents threaten to ‘flood the zone’ with immigration raids

Partner Resources:

Justice Action Center website on parole litigation

Have a story, update, or resource you want included in next month’s Let Them Stay Update? Contact Yael Schacher yschacher@refugeesinternational.org.

name: Human Rights
title: Larson, Crockett, and Jeffries Speak Out Against Trump Administration “Report” Targeting ...
description:
View Larson, Crockett, and Jeffries’ video here.
“If you truly believe that ICE is doing what they are supposed to be doing, then they wouldn’t be hiding their faces,” said Crockett.
“John Larson is on that list.
Jasmine Crockett is on that list.
I stand proudly, shoulder to shoulder, with John Larson, Jasmine Crockett, and all of my colleagues who the Trump Administration – the so-called Department of Homeland Security – has singled out for forcefully pushing back against them.”
text:
Washington, D.C. - After the U.S. Department of Homeland Security released a "report"(link is external) targeting Reps. John B. Larson (CT-01) and Jasmine Crockett (TX-30), and House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries(NY-08), for exercising their First Amendment rights to speak out against the Trump Administration, the members gathered on the Capitol steps to vow that they will not be silenced.

View Larson, Crockett, and Jeffries’ video here.(link is external)

“I am proud and honored to stand with my colleagues and be singled out by President Trump and his minions for standing up for the people in this country who this administration has gone after. This is a badge of honor,” said Larson.

“If you truly believe that ICE is doing what they are supposed to be doing, then they wouldn’t be hiding their faces,” said Crockett. “The rest of law enforcement don’t have to hide their faces because they are not going in and busting people’s windows and taking people down to the ground. So don’t be mad when we accurately describe what is taking place. It is a travesty. I don’t care if you are a Democrat, Republican, or Independent. You should all be offended and concerned if we allow any law enforcement in this country to treat anyone the way that they have treated even U.S. citizens.”

“The Department of Homeland Security has put out a list of people who have spoken out forcefully against the extremism being unleashed on the American people by Donald Trump,” said House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries. “John Larson is on that list. Jasmine Crockett is on that list. I’m on that list. It’s meant to intimidate us. It doesn’t intimidate us. It inspires us, because it’s clear we are doing the right thing on behalf of the American people. I stand proudly, shoulder to shoulder, with John Larson, Jasmine Crockett, and all of my colleagues who the Trump Administration – the so-called Department of Homeland Security – has singled out for forcefully pushing back against them.”

name: Litigation
outlet: University of Virginia School of Law
title: 'Admissible' S7 E2: Supreme Court Litigation Clinic at UVA Law
description:
XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah.
XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah.
NATALIE BLAZER: So you basically had your first-ever Supreme Court argument and your second-ever Supreme Court argument like a month apart.
XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah.
My guest today was UVA Law Supreme Court Litigation Clinic Director Xiao Wang.
text:
NATALIE BLAZER: It's pretty remarkable, if you think about it, that the client would choose a clinic of law students versus a Williams & Connolly or Covington, right?

XIAO WANG: Yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: Is this like pro bono?

XIAO WANG: So two things. One is, yes, we offer our services free of charge, right?

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah. [LAUGHING] The students aren't making billing hours for this.

XIAO WANG: You could see the car that I drove in on.

[LAUGHTER]

It was not a Lamborghini, so.

[THEME MUSIC]

NATALIE BLAZER: This is Admissible. I'm Natalie Blazer, Dean of Admissions at UVA Law. I'm so excited for today's episode not only because it's something I get questions about all the time from prospective students, but also because I think the topic we're discussing today is very relevant to the times that we're living in.

My guest today is Xiao Wang, director of the Supreme Court Litigation Clinic at UVA Law. He has led appeals and argued cases before the US Supreme Court, the federal courts of appeals, and other federal courts and agencies. In addition, he organizes the En Banc Institute and supervises the National Appellate Clinic Network, which was recognized as a finalist for Bloomberg Law's Law School Innovation Program.

Professor Wang previously worked as a litigator at Williams & Connolly and Wilkinson Steklov, where he led investigations or litigation on behalf of Mars, Under Armor, and the National Football League. Professor Wang writes about federal courts, constitutional law, and law and religion. His work has appeared in the Michigan Law Review, Vanderbilt Law Review, and Columbia Law Review Forum. And his popular writing has appeared in Bloomberg, The Chicago Tribune, and The Los Angeles Times.

Prior to joining the Law School, Professor Wang taught at Northwestern Pritzker School of Law as a clinical assistant professor and director of the Appellate Advocacy Center, where he supervised the Supreme Court and federal appellate clinics. Professor Wang clerked for Judge Karen N. Moore of the US Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit and Judge Lucy H. Koh of the US District Court for the Northern District of California. Although, I believe she's now on the Ninth Circuit.

Professor Wang earned his BA in economics and master's in public policy from the University of Virginia, where he was a Jefferson Scholar. He earned his JD from Yale Law School, where he was a Truman Scholar. Before law school, Professor Wang worked as a consultant at McKinsey & Co. What a bio. [LAUGHS] Welcome to the show, Professor Wang.

XIAO WANG: Hey, thanks so much for inviting me to be here. I'm really looking forward to it.

NATALIE BLAZER: I am, too. I am, too. So as a little icebreaker, I love asking people who were here for a time as students in Charlottesville and then went away and then came back-- because that's what I did-- but did you have any favorite spots as a student and either the same spots now as a professor or different?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah. There are some spots that have stayed constant favorites. So when I was a student here, the Bodo's on the corner actually opened--

NATALIE BLAZER: Mm!

XIAO WANG: --after a long awaited construction timeline. And so--

NATALIE BLAZER: Wow. Opened for the first time?

XIAO WANG: The Bodo's on the-- I think it opened in 2007 when I was an undergrad.

NATALIE BLAZER: Wow. So that's when I was in law school. I don't even think I realized that it was new at that point. That's cool.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, so that. The herb cream cheese and everything bagel has always been a steadfast constant for me. I would say one thing that's changed is, when I was a student here, for maybe a special once-a-year, maybe once-every-two-year treat, I would go to TenSushi or, you know. And luckily the Law School pays me well enough that I can go there a little bit more regularly-- not that much more regularly, but a little bit more. And they're obviously standouts in the Charlottesville dining.

NATALIE BLAZER: For sure. So speaking of your time here at UVA, even though you didn't go here for law school, you are a Double Hoo--

XIAO WANG: Yes.

NATALIE BLAZER: --because you got your undergrad and your masters. So how did you decide to come to UVA?

XIAO WANG: It was sort of a little bit on a lark. One of my friends from high school, his brother had come to UVA. And I grew up in Cincinnati, Ohio. And one of my friends from high school, his brother, had gone to UVA. And I'd been like, oh-- his brother was this three-sports star and head of the class. And when you're growing up in Ohio, not everyone even goes out of state.

NATALIE BLAZER: For sure.

XIAO WANG: So I asked him, I was like, well, why'd you decide to go out of state? And why did you decide to choose UVA and all that? And he said, well, it turns out I got this really great scholarship, the Jefferson Scholarship. And he told me all about it. And it sounded like this amazing package. It truly is an amazing package.

And I remember thinking, well, we were going to go on an East Coast college visit swing with my parents. And we decided to stop in Charlottesville. We literally took the scenic route and stopped by and saw the mountains and everything. And I sort of loved it.

And I remember going to the admissions committee open house. And I asked them about the Jefferson Scholarship because I was like, wow, this is a sweet deal, such a great deal. It's such a beautiful campus. How could you say no? And they were like, well, yeah, no one gets that.

[LAUGHTER]

So just try to apply and get in, and you'll have a great time here. So I sent in my application and applied to a couple other schools, as well. And I think each round of the Jefferson Scholarship-- it's this multi-round process. Each round, I don't know how it happened, but I would just make it to the next round and make it to the next round. And I ended up getting it.

I was incredibly fortunate, very privileged, very blessed to get it. And I mean, that makes the decision really easy, I think, because UVA is such an amazing school. The people here are just incredibly nice and kind and wonderful. The other students, the faculty at the undergrad are just fantastic. And it just made it a really easy decision to come here, and I've never regretted it.

NATALIE BLAZER: I love that story. "Nobody gets that." It just goes to show you you have to try. Don't let people get you down.

XIAO WANG: Exactly, exactly. So I'm very happy to report-- I don't even remember who the person from the admissions office was, but--

[LAUGHTER]

--yeah, definitely my parents and I laugh about that sometimes.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, I love it. So I think I read somewhere that it was during your time here in undergrad that you were maybe taking some law-related courses, I think even maybe from one of our current law school faculty.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: So tell me how that worked. And was that when your interest in maybe going to law school sparked?

XIAO WANG: Yeah. I think my interest-- my mom says my interest started when I was conscripted into doing mock trial as a sixth grader. And she was like, you become so passionate about this. And I think my parents were like-- my parents are both in the medical field. And they're like, he's never this passionate about Petri dishes.

[LAUGHTER]

And so I was like, yeah, I mean, fair, fair. But more seriously, at UVA, yeah, I got to know Micah Schwartzman quite a bit. And he had been a mentor for me when I was an undergrad. He had helped me navigate the Jefferson Scholarship process. He helped me navigate the Truman Scholarship process and some other postgraduate scholarships.

And I got to know him, and I thought, wow, what a fascinating career that he's had at that point. I was sort of a super dork in the time, and I read a little bit-- or tried to read a little bit-- of his Law Review work on academic scholarship. I was so fascinated.

So my last year in undergrad, I said, well-- [CHUCKLES] --I hope I can go to law school someday and maybe someday go to UVA. But in the meantime, do you mind if I just sit in on your constitutional law seminar? And I thought it was just amazing to see him and to also see the students really wrestle with these tough questions that the Supreme Court was wrestling with. And it just brought a level of rigor and a level of discussion that I didn't see in some of my other classes.

And so I think that was the time where I thought, well, yeah, I really do want to go to law school at some point. But I don't know if this is something that I should be telling on a podcast. So on a lark, I decided to take the LSAT without studying my senior year, and I did not do very well on it. [CHUCKLES] So I had to take a few years off to work for a few years and concentrate a little bit on studying for the LSAT and doing a lot better on it. And that opened a lot of doors.

NATALIE BLAZER: I'm glad you shared that, though, because I always say the LSAT is not a diagnostic, right? Like, you need to study for it.

XIAO WANG: For sure.

NATALIE BLAZER: Although, I have had guests on here who are like, I just took it, and then, yeah, great. I was like--

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I don't believe that.

[LAUGHTER]

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah. So you got your master's in public policy here.

XIAO WANG: Yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: And then, like you said, you worked for-- was it a couple years, McKinsey?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I worked for a couple years.

NATALIE BLAZER: OK. And then, ultimately you went to Yale Law School.

XIAO WANG: Yes.

NATALIE BLAZER: How was that experience?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I mean, I think Yale is really quite a different place than UVA in some ways. I mean, it took me a while to find my footing there. There were a couple other folks also that had gone to UVA undergrad that were there, and that was really nice to have that community.

In some ways, navigating Yale as just a different place at first. But I ended up finding a really good group of friends, a really good group of professors. I tried to spend none of the winters in New Haven, or the springs in New Haven.

[LAUGHTER]

And I really look back fondly, ultimately, on my law school experience. I think I have some lifelong friends and lifelong mentorships there.

NATALIE BLAZER: I think I saw you were in the Supreme Court Litigation Clinic at Yale Law School. So was that kind of-- I'm just curious. Were you sort of-- that's where your interests were going, this appellate-level litigation and the real clinical work?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I had a-- actually, this is one of the mentors I got to meet, was my first year. I got to take a class with Linda Greenhouse, who was then the New York Times' Supreme Court reporter.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, that's so cool.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I mean, I know she does some short courses here every few years. But it was just interesting to hear her talk about being at the Supreme Court, listening to argument, distilling it, and then teaching it to students, and all in the course of a week and a half.

And I really enjoyed the seminar. And she encouraged me to apply for the Supreme Court Clinic. And I ended up getting in. I think there's an application process. I can't really remember. And ended up getting in. And yeah, it took this idea of, hey, here's the cases you read, and now you're going to work on one that might end up setting law. So yeah, I thought that was really fun and interesting and unique to do in law school, also intimidating at first.

NATALIE BLAZER: I cannot even imagine. When you were in law school-- I'm curious-- because Yale's known for-- if you want to get into academia, I think a lot of people think about Yale and Harvard.

XIAO WANG: Yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: So were you surrounded by people who wanted to be law professors? Is that what you wanted to do? Or what was that like?

XIAO WANG: Oh, yeah. I mean, I think this podcast is trotting out all my embarrassments of my bombing the LSAT and-- in law school, actually, it's weird. There are a ton of people that want-- especially at Yale-- they want to be law professors one day. And I think I had entertained that. My dad is a professor of medicine. And I've always been interested a little bit in research. [CHUCKLES]

But it's sort of embarrassing. I think UVA has this, too. The Virginia Law Review has a similar process. But at Yale, you can write a student note, which is like this-- essentially, this short law review piece for-- a student writes it, a form of student scholarship. And you're encouraged to write your student notes and submit it and have them review it. And the best notes or whatever get chosen and published in the Yale Law Journal or the Virginia Law Review or whatever law school you're going to.

And-- [LAUGHS] --I mean, this is so embarrassing. When you send in a student note at Yale, they'll always send you back-- try to give you some feedback and try to send you back a memo. And usually the memo has three boxes that they can put your student note in. One is like, hey, this is amazing, and we're going to publish it. And we just need you to make a couple small changes and work with us to do that.

And the second box is, there's some idea here, but you really need to make all these changes and revise and maybe come resubmit. And then the third box is like, no, just don't come back. Please don't come back.

[LAUGHTER]

And I would say that-- they tell you up front. They're like, maybe 5% of pieces get in that first box that are accepted. And then 90% or 92% are in that second box of like, we think there's something here. And try to keep on improving and refining. They're like, very rare-- they tell you this at the start. They're like, very rarely will we ever put you in box 3, which is like, please don't come back, like do not pass Go again.

NATALIE BLAZER: [LAUGHS]

XIAO WANG: And I remember I submitted two notes for consideration. And both of them got box 3.

NATALIE BLAZER: Oh, my God!

XIAO WANG: [LAUGHS] And it was just like, I remember seeing that and being like, well, [CLICKS LIPS] probably just too dumb to be a law professor. Probably should give up this idea, this thing, and just be a big law lawyer or something.

So it did not work out as well when I was in law school. I'm happy to say it's worked out a little bit better since. But yeah, there were definitely a lot of people that were interested in it. And I just honestly didn't know if I was cut out for it.

NATALIE BLAZER: I love that story. It's very real. And I think it helps people who-- first of all, when I welcomed our 1Ls on Friday, I said, while you are here in law school, try out for things, go for things. You will fail sometimes, but you have to try. And that story is just such a great example of like, what if you had just decided, I guess I'm not cut out for it. I mean, you can't take those things to heart. You have to keep trying. So I love that story.

XIAO WANG: Yeah. Yeah, I mean, I think one thing that was helpful, I had a professor in law school, and I had gone up to her. She was a real mentor to me. I was her RA. I was her TA. Got this amazing, fantastic record, like a Rhodes scholar, Yale Law School, and everything, and this incredible CV. And I talked to her about some of these struggles, and I was pretty candid about it.

And she said something that was really helpful for me to think about. And she was like, the CV that you see on the website or the resume you see for your professors or for these big law partners or whatever, those are the greatest hits of their lives. And they never talk about any of their greatest misses. And sometimes you learn the most from your greatest misses. And I think that helped a lot because I think that all of us have things that we wish it panned out differently, but we learn a lot from when they don't-- when they don't work out.

XIAO WANG: Totally, totally. So across the country, there are, I think, 12 to 13-- depends on how you count one of the circuits-- but there's 12 to 13 federal courts of appeals. And they hear appeals from these trial courts, which is where cases start. And they're the intermediate layer between the trial court and the Supreme Court.

And usually, when you bring an appeal in those courts, your appeal is heard by this panel of three judges. And they end up voting. And because there's three judges, they always come up with a decision. It's like two to one, or three-nothing, or what have you.

And what that means is that the court itself, the appeals court itself, might have 15 or 18 judges. And when you seek en banc review, you say, look, I think these three judges that heard my first appeal didn't get it right. I want it to be heard by the big 15-judge court.

Sometimes folks will choose that route. And other times, they'll choose to just go straight to the Supreme Court. Either way, en banc courts end up-- when the court decides to take up a case and hear it en banc, all the judges in that court, it's usually a pretty big deal. And often, it's a preview of what might come up in the Supreme Court going forward because if 15 judges on the appellate court say this is an important enough issue we want to take up, the Supreme Court might be like, well, this is an important issue. XIAO WANG: Yeah, I think--

NATALIE BLAZER: Or are they-- so this didn't even occur to me until right now. Is this pro bono?

XIAO WANG: So two things. One is, yes, we offer our services free of charge, right?

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah. The students aren't making billing hours for this.

[LAUGHTER]

XIAO WANG: You could see the car that I drove in on. It was not a Lamborghini.

[LAUGHTER]

So we offer our services free of charge. But a lot of law firms do, too. And I think--

NATALIE BLAZER: Because of the prestige?

XIAO WANG: Yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: OK.

XIAO WANG: Because of the prestige, because of the marketing value, the experience that it affords. First of all, I certainly lead with and talk about how remarkable our students are. And that's because of your work, honestly. You find really great folks.

NATALIE BLAZER: Aw, thank you.

XIAO WANG: And so I just coast on your laurels, Natalie.

NATALIE BLAZER: [LAUGHS]

XIAO WANG: I say it's not just the students. It's certainly not just me. I mean, we have an incredible faculty here and an incredible librarian staff and an incredible set of staff and researchers. And that's something that a lot of other places don't have.

And so I've been on pitch meetings where I say, look, the lower court that decided your case, also, in deciding your case, cited an article by Aditya Bamzai. Guess where he works? He works four doors down from me, and I can just call him.

NATALIE BLAZER: Right, he's a law professor here. So cool.

XIAO WANG: And so I think that that provides us a comparative advantage. But it's an incredibly competitive clinic.

NATALIE BLAZER: So competitive. Any case that goes before the Supreme Court, I imagine-- I mean, there's going to be some venue issues, I know, that maybe are not that controversial. But this one, I know, had some controversy surrounding it. And so, first of all, how do you talk students through that?

I'm just curious because for-- I'll just reiterate for listeners, this was a reverse discrimination issue, basically a straight, cisgender, white woman saying, if I'm discriminated against-- in other words, she was not promoted in favor of an LGBTQ+ person who was promoted, and then she was demoted. Basically, my understanding is, OK, well, if you are claiming reverse discrimination, you actually have a higher burden to meet than if the reverse fact pattern was true. And so you could see that that would push some people to--

XIAO WANG: Yeah, totally.

NATALIE BLAZER: So what conversations happen either within the clinic, or do you hear from people even outside of the clinic? How does that work?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, well, certainly I hear from people outside of the clinic, for sure. For sure. I mean, I think it's incredibly tough to land one of these cases. But it's also incredibly tough to advocate and figure out what the strategy is and to hear all the noise from outside. I mean, that can be really distracting. And it can be really tough at times. I'm definitely not going to sugarcoat it.

And to your point, it's not relegated to just this more high profile case. I mean, in our other case that we argued had to do with retirement benefits. And a few of my friends who work in finance, who aren't in law, would call me and be like, I can't believe you're doing this! This is going to ruin my relationship with my clients and everything!

NATALIE BLAZER: And meanwhile, I'm thinking, that's pretty dry.

XIAO WANG: I know, I know!

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, yeah.

XIAO WANG: And so whenever it gets to the Supreme Court, there's going to be some level of controversy, whether it's the broader public or it's a smaller section of people that are really invested or interested in the issue. And I think what I try to tell our students is like, we're not going to be-- our clinic will never be like Michael Avenatti. We're not going to be out in the press, trying to advocate our case.

I think what we want to do is we want to work with our clients. We want to come up with the best legal strategy. And we want to put that forward and base that based on research, precedent, fact, text, and see where we go. And I think we have a good track record there. And I'm really proud of that track record.

But I think, with our students, to me, I've tried to emphasize that when it gets tough and when there's-- I certainly don't want them to feel that-- feel any opprobrium or anything like that. But I think I try to flip it around and say, look, this is a really good learning experience.

It really is a way to-- I mean, because when you're at a big law firm, often you're going to take positions that are unpopular and may, in fact, be wrong. Like, who knows? And I think figuring out and navigating like, hey, what's real out there and what's the law say, and how do we advocate for this fairly and with integrity, I mean, those are really key questions that we want students to really develop and learn and think about as they navigate through law school.

NATALIE BLAZER: It's like what moot court is all about, or what mock trial is all about. You're arguing for a position that you don't necessarily agree with. When I was in big law, one of our biggest clients was like Philip Morris. Do I agree with anything that Philip Morris does? Not necessarily. But you see how arguments get made. You see the creativity of arguments for a client like that. And I think that's all toward the good for developing young lawyers.

I also tell students like, the Supreme Court is what it is right now. So any chance you have to see how they-- this is going to be probably the makeup of the court for many, many years to come. And so for our students who are graduating and practicing, this is going to be where we're at. I'm curious actually, now that we're talking about that, do you talk to them about the Supreme Court itself? Like, in this day of 2025, they are under scrutiny. Are they really independent? What's going on with the Trump administration? How much does that come into play, or not really?

XIAO WANG: Yeah. Well, I want to hop back really quick. I think this will tie back into your question. One thing that I think did make a difference-- and it is something really, really critical for me as a professor, especially that I want to bring to my students-- is to really get a sense to know our clients.

So I made sure they all got to know Marlene Ames because it's really, really easy to make generalizations and come up with narratives or stories or stereotypes or whatever. But if you meet her, I mean, such a sweet woman.

And to get a chance to meet her and talk to her and see, hey, this is a woman that went from working her decades at a social services agency, ending up well-reviewed, well-regarded, ended up pulling herself up to make about $100,000 a year, and was a single mom supporting two kids, and to lose that and to have her salary cut in half for something that she really doesn't why she got, I think that puts a human face to things. And it becomes a lot harder to say, well, we should be up here, when really what's going on is working with an individual and trying to get them to have the courthouse doors open for them. So I think that really matters.

I think your broader question about the Supreme Court, to me, I think working with the students on the cases and seeing how we were able to craft arguments that had support from all sides really, actually, I hope gave them some faith in the system to say, like, hey, at the end, you really want to come up with arguments that appeal to everybody and really sound and work for everyone. But there's no question that there's a broader discussion about the Supreme Court's role and the makeup of the court and how it plays within our society today.

And I don't want to-- I certainly don't shut the door to those discussions. I mean, the last couple of years, I've had Bertrall Ross, who used to be part of our faculty, come in. He was part of President Biden's commission to look at the Supreme Court. And I've had him come in and talk about the broader structural place of the Supreme Court. And we do have those discussions, for sure. And I think those discussions enrich the experience.

That said, there are, I think, so many classes at UVA that have those discussions. I think our thought is, we're working there in front of them. How do we do the best and get justice for our clients?

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, I think both are important. Like, we're working-- like I said, this is what we have.

XIAO WANG: Exactly.

NATALIE BLAZER: We're not changing the Supreme Court anytime soon. We're working with what we have. But also, I think, to Bertrall's point, we can also think critically about where this is going and all that. So Ames was your second time arguing before the Supreme Court. Walk me through-- the clinic is mooting you, my guess.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, totally.

NATALIE BLAZER: So how long are you preparing before this?

XIAO WANG: We were so busy. Once the case is granted, you'll file what's known as your opening merits brief. The other side files their response brief. And you file a reply brief. And our cases were back-to-back months. And so our reply brief-- I argued in front of the Supreme Court, I think, January 22. That was my first argument, January 22 of this year.

NATALIE BLAZER: And that was the Cunningham retirement benefits case.

XIAO WANG: Yeah. And my birthday was two days later.

[LAUGHTER]

And so I took, I guess, two or three days off for my birthday. So that's late January. And then by February 7, we had to file our reply brief in Ames. And when you're filing your reply brief, you're not thinking about oral argument. You're just trying to get the reply. This is the last written word you get in front of the Court.

So that's February 7. And I think the argument was February 24 or 26. So it's like 2 and 1/2 weeks. And basically, those 2 and 1/2 weeks, I think I did three or four moots at different places. But yeah, I remember we sent in our reply brief. I think I took a nap. And then the next day--

NATALIE BLAZER: [LAUGHS]

XIAO WANG: I mean, this is the great thing. Usually, my first moot is with our students. And it is always hilariously bad.

[LAUGHTER]

And honestly, I think it would not get past the quarterfinals of the Wild Moot Court Competition. It's so bad. I think, for my first moot in Cunningham, I'll be honest, I think some of the students had some questions.

[LAUGHTER]

But then my last moot is also with the students. And I think they can see-- and I think that's helpful because I think, in the end when you see it, you're like, wow, they were able to answer the questions. They were cool under fire. And they had a ready answer. And it's not like that. It's this random set of pieces at the start. And you see it coming together over moot 1, 2, 3, 4. And it ends in a good place. But to see it build, I think that's a good learning opportunity for the students.

NATALIE BLAZER: So you basically had your first-ever Supreme Court argument and your second-ever Supreme Court argument like a month apart.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: We're kind of flip-flopping now between Cunningham and Ames, but I think that's OK. What was your first argument like? Were you terrified?

XIAO WANG: I felt pretty prepped. I don't know if I was terrified as much as-- there's a certain amount of pomp and circumstance that goes with arguing before the Supreme Court. And that's really interesting and really fun. I mean, you get to be on the stage. And you get to be in the lawyers lounge beforehand and prep your notes. And the person that I was arguing against, my opposing counsel, had argued 33 times or something beforehand.

NATALIE BLAZER: [GASPS] Wow.

XIAO WANG: And so I think that-- I wouldn't say I was terrified. It was just sort of like taking the court for the first time and trying to understand what it was like. I will say we were the second argument that day. And the first argument was about this police shooting, Fourth Amendment question.

And when you're the second argument, you sit behind the first argument. And you sit behind the first argument, and the Supreme Court is like, I don't know, 30 feet high. It's incredibly-- it's this cavernous, majestic building courtroom. And where you sit, if you're the second argument, is right under the lights. And it's like a heat lamp.

[LAUGHTER]

So I remember going to the bathroom a couple times just because you would be--

NATALIE BLAZER: Just sweating.

XIAO WANG: You're baking. You're baked Alaska out there. And then you're trying to drink some water. And then you're like, I need to go to the bathroom. And you're like, I hope they don't call my case.

[LAUGHTER]

And so I think that actually takes some pressure off because instead of thinking about, what am I going to say, you're like, I honestly need to just have an empty bladder and a not sore throat when I get up there.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, yeah. And so, that case, was it 9-0?

XIAO WANG: Yes. Yeah, yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: Congratulations.

XIAO WANG: Oh, thank you.

NATALIE BLAZER: That's incredible.

XIAO WANG: Oh, thanks.

NATALIE BLAZER: And Ames was also 9-0.

XIAO WANG: Yep, yep. Thank you.

NATALIE BLAZER: I mean, so this is why now you don't have to go out and find cases anymore. [LAUGHS]

XIAO WANG: I definitely still do. I definitely still do. I wish I didn't, but yeah, it's always great to see that for the clients. But yeah, they're still hard work to be done. Don't worry about that.

NATALIE BLAZER: I have no doubt. Did these clinic students just get extremely lucky to have two cases going on at the same time? Or is that normal?

XIAO WANG: I don't know if they would say they were extremely lucky. I think in retrospect they would. But during the time when we were working on it, I mean, I think we put in a lot of hours and a lot of time. And the students were remarkable. This isn't just all we were doing. We had some other cases we were working on. And they put in really, really fantastic work.

They hold a really special place in my heart for all the work, but really all my students because I tell them-- and when I say that they've done such great work, it was actually-- they worked on the merits cases. But the last year, the students before that worked on the cert petition. So it's like, I've really been blessed with multiple classes of incredibly hardworking and incredibly intelligent students.

I think they were very fortunate this year. They got to go to the Supreme Court several times to watch the argument, to see how the Justices react. They got to go-- the Biden and Trump administration supported us in both cases. And when that happens, you actually work as a tag team with the Solicitor General's office, which is the office within the Justice Department that argues Supreme Court cases. And so we'll go up there, and we'll just sit around a table with members of the Solicitor General's office and think about strategy, think about argument. And that's an opportunity that I almost never got in a law firm.

NATALIE BLAZER: I was gonna say, that's very rare. I mean, and they're getting that? That's awesome.

XIAO WANG: We got to moot at what's known as Georgetown Supreme Court Institute and got to see Georgetown faculty ask us tough questions on both of our cases. And so I think that they had an incredible amount of opportunities. I'm really glad we were able to give it to them. And I think, in exchange, they all put in a lot of time. And very, very grateful for that.

NATALIE BLAZER: That makes me so happy, makes me so proud of them. Do you know what this upcoming year-- what cases you're working on?

XIAO WANG: I do.

NATALIE BLAZER: If you can't share, that's OK.

XIAO WANG: No, no, no, I can share a little bit about it. I think we've had a case that's been pending, which is this Fourth Amendment case about dog sniffs.

NATALIE BLAZER: Oooh.

XIAO WANG: And basically there's a question-- there's an open question in the lower courts that if you get stopped and a dog goes around and sniffs your car-- if they just go around and sniff your car and they don't touch your car, it's actually constitutional. The Supreme Court has already decided that question.

But there's an open question of, what happens if the dog walks around and say you have your window open and they just jump through your window and then-- they jump through the window because they think they smell drugs or whatever? Is jumping through your window, is that considered a trespass? And if that's a trespass, is that a Fourth Amendment violation?

So we represent an individual out of Iowa. Her name's Ashley Mumford. And we are arguing that that is considered a Fourth Amendment search. And so right now, that's in the very final stages of briefing. I actually need to finish writing the reply brief by next Tuesday. So--

NATALIE BLAZER: Oh, my goodness!

XIAO WANG: --four days from now.

[LAUGHTER]

NATALIE BLAZER: So just so I understand, you're arguing that that is a lawful--

XIAO WANG: An unlawful search.

NATALIE BLAZER: Unlawful, OK.

XIAO WANG: Unlawful search, yeah.

NATALIE BLAZER: Fourth Amendment violation.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, and the other side, represented by the Iowa Attorney General's Office, says that that's totally fine.

NATALIE BLAZER: And presumably this would only come up if something was found when the dog jumps through the window. So student listeners out there, you will learn all about this in crim law, fruit of the poisonous tree, and all that stuff. So wow, ooh, I can't wait to hear how this goes.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I think we really hope for the best for our client. I mean, I think that this is an issue that definitely comes up. I mean, police use dogs all the time. And often, they ask you to roll down your window to give your license and registration. So I think that what-- I think it's definitely an interesting issue.

We have another case that involves what's known as venue, which I mentioned earlier. It's, where do you file a lawsuit? Incidentally, that case has to do with a dog bite. So we are the canine--

[LAUGHTER]

--canine-themed clinic this year. And then, finally, we're working on some other matters that have to do with environmental law, with retirement law-- employee benefits law, and voting rights. So those are operating in the background.

NATALIE BLAZER: Really cool. Do a lot of students in the clinic have aspirations to clerk or to even clerk for the Supreme Court?

XIAO WANG: Certainly, I think probably more so than the general population of students at the law school. And--

NATALIE BLAZER: I imagine it helps them be competitive for a clerkship to go through the clinic.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, I mean, I think it's just a conversation. And I'm sure that Scott Ballinger has the same conversation with his appellate litigation clinic. But a lot of the times-- or many times, judges-- if you apply for a clerkship, judges will call your references or your recommenders. Or they'll call me, for instance. And I can say really great things about all my students, that I do end up saying.

But it's one thing saying, like, hey, this is a great student, to say-- it's one thing to say that. And it's another thing to say, this is a student that worked on a merits case for the Supreme Court. And they wrote this section of the brief. I can tell you that. Their name can't be on it, but I can tell you that.

And if I trust them with an argument that goes before the Supreme Court, I think that that's a level of credibility and legitimacy that would be really helpful for a judicial law clerk. So I think that those conversations really matter. And I think it's been really, really supportive of our students in being able to apply for and land clerkships.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah. Before we wrap up, because I know you have this reply brief to work on-- [LAUGHS]

XIAO WANG: It's all good.

NATALIE BLAZER: --I really want to return to what you said about human client. All these cases before the Supreme Court involve people. At the end of the day, they involve people. This venue question that might sound super boring-- someone got bitten by a dog, presumably-- just because you hear "Fourth Amendment" or whatever Amendment, it's like, this is a person, or these are people.

So I'm curious. Now that you've argued before the Supreme Court twice and you see the judges, do you see students feeling conflicted about clerking for certain judges? I'm asking because of how political everything is now. Everything is political. But like we were talking about before, this is the Supreme Court we have.

And you have made two arguments where all nine agree. So in theory, we can agree on things, right? So I just feel that this is so important to talk about today. How would you talk to a student or counsel a student who maybe is someone who could clerk on the Supreme Court but feels conflicted because of their own personal values?

XIAO WANG: Well, first, I'd say apply and hopefully be in our clinic because I think every year that I've taught, including the time when I taught at Northwestern, but certainly at UVA, we've had students of all political persuasions, backgrounds, racial, gender, religious backgrounds. And that is a real strength of UVA.

And really thanks to the admissions committee for finding those folks because what it means is that we can talk about these issues. And we can't talk about it just in the abstract. We have to represent our client. And we can say, all right, I know you guys come from different backgrounds. You have different views. But how do we come up with something that would make sense, that you could understand, that you could agree with? Because that's going to be what's going to work with the Supreme Court. And I think that is something that I really value and treasure.

I think for the students, though, I would also say, look, you learn a ton from clerking and from working and from seeing how the law is formed and established and how to be a great advocate. And you'll use those skills. And there are definitely going to be times where you work for a judge or where you work for a law firm that you may not agree with everything, and that's OK. People don't agree with a lot of things. And that's OK.

I think what is something that you can take from it is like, what can I learn? How can I be a better advocate? How can I work with my clients? How can I come up with what I hope are arguments that folks can really agree with from across the aisle? And if that works, I think that's-- then I'm doing my job.

And I would really counsel students to say, certainly there's a degree of politics, there's a degree of partisanship and polarization in society at large, and in the legal system perhaps, as well. But you can either add to it, or you can try to work through it and maybe turn down the temperature a bit. And I've always mentioned to my students that I really want to be a person that turns down the temperature and thinks about how we can really advocate for our clients and come up with things that are workable for everyone.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, I love that. You can add to the polarization. You can do what you're doing, which is turn down the temperature. Or you can sit out entirely, which is almost the worst option. So getting in there, understanding how it works, the difficulty of crafting an argument, that will get that 9-0 ruling, I mean, I think that's what it's all about.

XIAO WANG: I mean, I think it's totally right. And I think that one thing with Ames in particular, I remember, is one of the professors-- I'm not going to name names-- one professor-- a couple professors actually told me-- they were like, well, if you just change this argument and really played into a grievance narrative or whatever, you could just win it 6-3, and it could be a lot easier for you.

And I just told them-- I just looked at them. And I said, like, yeah, we're not going to do that. We're definitely not going to do that because I don't think that gets us anywhere. And I think that it's certainly probably harder to come up with universal arguments, to come up with the research, and to listen through to the precedents and the texts and to really investigate the history behind certain clauses and how to interpret them.

But I think what comes out is a better product for everyone that we can agree with. And that takes work for me. It takes a ton of work for me. It takes a ton of work for my staff. It takes a ton of work for our students. But I think that's what we want to teach our students at the end of the day. And I am really fortunate for the Law School's support behind that.

NATALIE BLAZER: Yeah, that resonates with what I tell our students all the time. I mean, it is going to be hard work. Trying to do it the easy way or trying to do-- that's never going to get us where we want to be. I mean, we're UVA Law. Why should we be trying to take the easy route?

XIAO WANG: Well, when you said something about, you could turn up the temperature or turn it down or sit on the sidelines, I think that-- and I don't want listeners to take this the wrong way, but I think that if you're a UVA Law student, I really don't think you can or should sit on the sidelines. You have already proven that you're incredibly gifted and talented, sharp and precocious. And you have this privilege to be able to really help people and to work in a legal system and improve that legal system. And I think sitting out on that is something that society loses out on, but you definitely lose out on.

NATALIE BLAZER: For sure, yeah. I tell them, remember why you applied to law school in the first place. Sitting out is-- I agree-- completely not an option. And I have been, honestly, so inspired by this conversation. It makes me so happy that you're here.

It makes me so proud of all of the students. I'm going to go back and look up who was in the clinic each year because it makes me so excited for our 3L's who are about to have this experience. So before we go, because most listeners are thinking about applying to law school or they're getting ready to apply to law school, what advice would you give based on everything we've talked about, your own experience?

XIAO WANG: Yeah, when it comes to applying to law school, I think that, in some ways, as you craft your application, some things are set, like your LSAT score and your undergraduate GPA. But I think what I would say is, hey, what's not said are, make sure you have a great set of recommenders and references. Make sure you keep up with those folks. And write a personal statement that reflects who you are.

And I think, as things come in, have an open mind about where you want to attend and go to. I'm certain, for some people, they may not think of Charlottesville, Virginia as a place that they could imagine themselves. But then they come here, and they fall in love with this place. So I would just say, have an open mind. And if UVA is something that you're interested in, my email is on the website. I'm happy to talk and be a booster for this place.

NATALIE BLAZER: That's so nice. And as we've talked about, in the middle of everything you're working on, that's very generous. So thank you. This was awesome.

XIAO WANG: Thank you. I appreciate it. This was great.

NATALIE BLAZER: This was so, so fun. Thank you so much for taking the time. I know you have just so much going on. You just got married.

XIAO WANG: Yes.

NATALIE BLAZER: Congratulations.

XIAO WANG: Thank you.

NATALIE BLAZER: I'm glad you're back from all your travels. And I'm excited to see what you guys do this year.

XIAO WANG: Yeah, yeah. Same, same. Hopefully we'll be able to get some great opportunities again for our students.

[THEME MUSIC]

This has been Admissible with me, Dean Natalie Blazer, at the University of Virginia School of Law. My guest today was UVA Law Supreme Court Litigation Clinic Director Xiao Wang. For more information about UVA Law, please visit law.virginia.edu.

The next episode of Admissible will be out soon. In the meantime, you can follow the show on Instagram at @Admissible podcast. Thanks so much for listening. And please remember to rate the show wherever you listen to podcasts.

text:
The following statement was signed by 108 civil rights, faith-based and labor organizations and published by The Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights:

Whether we’re Black, White, Brown, Latino, Asian, Arab, or Indigenous, Native or newcomer, LGBTQ+or not, disabled or not, and regardless of faith, we believe in the freedom to speak out against injustice, organize for change, and fight hate and discrimination through peaceful means. It is not just a right, but a duty to the communities we represent. That’s why civil rights groups have criticized acts of this administration and denounced offensive and dangerous rhetoric.

This administration has made clear its intent to protect discrimination over civil rights and use any opportunity to silence dissent and target nonprofits that oppose its policies. It attacks philanthropic institutions, unions, teachers, and universities that support diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, the freedom to protest and to learn our history. We cannot be silent as they turn government power against our rights.

We continue to unequivocally condemn all forms of violence, including political violence, as our communities have long been targets of white supremacists’ hatred. America’s civil rights movement is rooted in nonviolence – as championed by Dr. King and Bayard Rustin—from the Montgomery Bus Boycott and the March on Washington to today’s fight for equal opportunity for all.

Our communities face the highest rates of hate and violence –including anti-Arab, anti-Asian, anti-Black, anti-homeless, anti-immigrant, anti-Latino, anti-LGBTQ+, anti-Muslim, antisemitic, and gender-based violence— and this administration’s actions and rhetoric have only intensified the dangers of hate crimes and violence by militarizing our cities, demonizing these communities, and enabling mass raids based on race and immigration status.

In an effort to silence opposition, the administration now also threatens to designate civil rights groups as “domestic terrorists,” revoke their non-profit status, and launch criminal investigations. But no group or individual should be considered a “criminal” for documenting hate incidents, protecting vulnerable communities, and pursuing justice through courts and legislation rather than violence.

The First Amendment protects our right to assemble, petition our government, and speak truth to power. These are not privileges—they are fundamental rights. Our strength has always come from unity built on freedom, not fear; on debate, not silence. When an administration seeks to stifle dissent, it rejects the very spirit that carries this nation forward. That’s why we:

Call on Congress to reject these attacks and publicly defend organizations exercising their constitutional rights,

Call on our allies to speak up now, because in unity, there is strength, and

Call on all Americans to recognize this attack for what it is: an assault on the institutions that protect all our rights.

Further attacks will only strengthen our conviction—a conviction driven not by greed, power, or envy, but by the fundamental belief that all people, regardless of race or identity, deserve equality, fairness, and dignity.

text:
PHILADELPHIA — A former Liberian rebel general was sentenced Sept. 11 to more than four years in prison for concealing serious human rights violations to fraudulently obtain immigration status in the United States. Laye Sekou Camara, 47, of Mays Landing, New Jersey, entered the United States on an immigrant visa and lied on his immigration forms by failing to admit he was involved in Liberia’s civil war.

“As a leader in Liberia’s civil war, Mr. Camara facilitated atrocities against civilians in his own country — including the use of child soldiers,” said ICE’s Homeland Security Investigations Philadelphia Special Agent in Charge Edward V. Owens. “By concealing his crimes in Liberia, Camara was able to obtain immigration benefits and use those documents to seek employment and a new life in the United States. HSI will not allow the U.S. to become a refuge for human rights violators or for individuals who secure lawful status through deception. We will continue to work with our federal, state and international partners to identify fraud, protect the integrity of the immigration system, and support the prosecutors that hold these offenders accountable.”

According to the investigation, in 2010, Camara obtained lawful permanent resident status by falsely stating on immigration forms that he had never participated in extrajudicial killings or other acts of violence; had never been involved with a paramilitary unit, rebel group, or guerilla group; and had never engaged in the recruitment or use of child soldiers.

HSI Philadelphia investigated the case with assistance from the Pennsylvania Office of Attorney General and the U.S. Department of State’s Diplomatic Security Service at the U.S. Embassy in Monrovia, and with support from the Human Rights Violators and War Crimes Center.

text:
Canada has reported a sharp jump in asylum claims from people fleeing across the border from the United States, as the Trump administration intensifies its hardline stance on immigration.

Officials in Canada said they have received more than 5,500 asylum claims since the beginning of July at one border crossing – Quebec’s Saint-Bernard-de-Lacolle border crossing, south of Montreal.

The figure represents a 263% increase from the same period last year, according to data from the Canada Border Services Agency.

The spike in border crossings comes as President Trump ramps up military-style raids by armed, masked, agents of the Department for Homeland Security’s Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agency as the White House presses them to hit deportation targets.

The Trump administration’s operation is targeting immigrants in the U.S. illegally with criminal records, and has seen over 200,000 people arrested, and over 50,000 detained so far this year. Many are being seized from their homes, while going to work, outside courthouses and at store parking lots.

Many of those arrested and detained have had previous protections allowing them to legally remain in the U.S. removed by the government.

Earlier this year the Trump administration revoked temporary legal status granted to more than 800,000 immigrants who fled violence, disasters and instability in countries like Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela.

This week, Trump deployed the National Guard to Memphis and suggested he could also send troops into Chicago. The White House has previously sent them into Los Angeles and Washington D.C.

As well as those who may face deportation from the U.S. trying to flee the country, increasing numbers of U.S. citizens are also trying to leave, the Canadian figures suggest.

Data from the Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada covering claims of alleged persecution within the U.S. last month revealed there were 245 refugee applications made by U.S. citizens in the first six months of this year.

This represents a sharp rise in claims, with 204 referrals filed by Americans in the whole of 2024.

Canada’s acceptance of U.S. refugees has historically been low. Applicants must convince the board that nowhere in the U.S. offers them safety to gain asylum.

The Canadian data does not specify why Americans are seeking refugee status north of the border, a nation which Trump has said he wants to become the 51st U.S. state.

name: Policy
title: Biden offered health insurance access to DACA immigrants. Trump took it away. • Stateline
description:
A new Trump administration rule bars immigrants living in the United States under Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) from buying health insurance from Affordable Care Act marketplaces.
More than 20% of all DACA recipients reside in just two of those states: Texas (17%) and Florida (4%).
Mohyeddin and her colleagues surveyed 433 DACA recipients in 2024, before DACA recipients were eligible for the marketplace.
Eighty-one percent had health coverage, the vast majority through their employer or a union or professional association.
“The stripping of eligibility is a devastating step backwards, not only for DACA recipients, but families and immigrant communities in general,” Mohyeddin said.
text:
A new Trump administration rule bars immigrants living in the United States under Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) from buying health insurance from Affordable Care Act marketplaces.

The change, announced in June, took effect at the beginning of this month. It reverses a policy change enacted by the Biden administration for last November’s annual enrollment period.

DACA, which President Barack Obama established in 2012, applies to certain immigrants who are here illegally but were brought to the U.S. as children. The program was enacted to protect them from deportation and allows them to work for renewable two-year periods. To be eligible, an immigrant must have come to the U.S. at age 15 or younger before June 15, 2007. DACA participants also must be high school graduates, high school students or veterans of the U.S. military.

The oldest are now in their early 40s, some with children of their own.

Even though there are some 525,000 active DACA recipients, only about 10,000 were getting their health insurance from the marketplaces before the policy change, according to the federal Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services. However, critics of the new Trump administration rule say participation would have grown as more people became aware of their eligibility.

Under pressure, some immigrants are leaving American dreams behind

DACA recipients from 19 states were blocked from the marketplaces, though, because of pending litigation. More than 20% of all DACA recipients reside in just two of those states: Texas (17%) and Florida (4%).

Jessica Vaughan, director of policy studies at the Center for Immigration Studies, a nonprofit group that backs stricter immigration rules, said DACA was an “abuse of executive authority” and should not have entitled some immigrants to benefits. The rule change simply restores the status quo, Vaughan said.

“It was kind of an experiment or an end run around our legal immigration system that was set up by the rules that were set up by Congress to try to offer an amnesty to this particular group,” Vaughan said. “Because it’s not a legal status, these individuals are not, under the law, eligible for certain public benefits, and one of them is subsidized health insurance.”

But critics of the change say it’s cruel to cancel health care coverage for people who were brought to the country as children.

“Health care is a fundamental human right all of us, no matter where we were born, how much money we have, what we look like, what language we speak, we should be able to access quality and affordable care when we need it,” said Isobel Mohyeddin, a policy associate at the National Immigration Law Center, which advocates for immigrants.

Mohyeddin and her colleagues surveyed 433 DACA recipients in 2024, before DACA recipients were eligible for the marketplace. Eighty-one percent had health coverage, the vast majority through their employer or a union or professional association. But nearly 20% lacked coverage, more than twice the national uninsured rate of 8%.

Mohyeddin said that many of the DACA recipients without coverage reported skipping recommended medical and dental appointments or declining to fill prescriptions, because they couldn’t afford it or were fearful of being targeted for their status.

“The stripping of eligibility is a devastating step backwards, not only for DACA recipients, but families and immigrant communities in general,” Mohyeddin said.

While DACA recipients were only recently allowed to purchase coverage on the marketplace, it was a huge step toward better health outcomes for them, said Arline Cruz Escobar, director of health programs at Make the Road New York, a group that provides legal and social services to immigrants.

Most refugees and asylees will be denied food stamps under Trump’s new law

“We see a lot of mixed-status households, and so I think people are just very confused about what this means for them, and what it means for their families,” Cruz Escobar said. “We already know that the immigrant community doesn’t access enough preventive care and screenings and so, I can only imagine that we will see an increase in a lot of chronic conditions, or undiagnosed chronic conditions that could have been prevented.”

The impact of the new Trump administration rule on DACA recipients will vary, as some states offer other health care options to noncitizens.

States are going to have to decide whether they can afford to offer state-subsidized health coverage to DACA recipients and other immigrants who are no longer eligible for federal help, said Jessica Altman, executive director of California’s marketplace exchange, Covered California.

California has the most DACA recipients, at 147,440. Altman said more than 2,300 of them have purchased plans on the California marketplace and will lose their coverage. She said many DACA recipients in the state were not aware of their eligibility, and more would have enrolled if the Trump administration hadn’t made the policy change.

California provides state-funded health coverage to all income-eligible immigrants, regardless of their legal status. But Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom in June signed a budget that scales back that coverage because of budgetary issues.

In light of federal changes and financial obligations on states, Altman said, California will have to make the same choices as other states about how or whether to help DACA recipients with their health care.

“The hard part is, to actually make coverage affordable for the populations that we’re talking about, you have to fund financial assistance at least somewhat comparable to what’s available on the federal marketplace,” Altman said. “So the state dollars are really where the rubber meets the road.”

Stateline reporter Shalina Chatlani can be reached at schatlani@stateline.org.

title: ICE provides more info about dramatic arrest outside Hartford courthouse - NBC Connecticut
description:
We have learned new information about the man taken into ICE custody outside of Hartford Superior Court Sept. 10.
It took ICE less than 90 seconds to take him down, and eight days to release information about it.
Castiano-Rojas was on the docket for charges including promoting prostitution and running a drug factory in Hartford.
By 2016, he was back in the U.S. again, allegedly running a drug and prostitution ring, according to court documents.
Castiano-Rojas’ co-defendant, Carlos Camargo, was picked up by ICE the day before him last week, inside the courthouse.
text:
We have learned new information about the man taken into ICE custody outside of Hartford Superior Court Sept. 10.

Our camera was the only one rolling when agents grabbed Mauricio Castiano-Rojas.

It took ICE less than 90 seconds to take him down, and eight days to release information about it.

Castiano-Rojas was on the docket for charges including promoting prostitution and running a drug factory in Hartford.

But he never got inside the courthouse, swarmed by eight agents in the middle of Lafayette Street, something that’s still pretty rare to see here.

ICE told us he first entered the country illegally in 2007 and was returned to Mexico.

By 2016, he was back in the U.S. again, allegedly running a drug and prostitution ring, according to court documents.

Castiano-Rojas’ co-defendant, Carlos Camargo, was picked up by ICE the day before him last week, inside the courthouse.

Both men are from Mexico. They are being held now in separate facilities in New Hampshire and Rhode Island.

title: Congress prepares to vote on short-term funding bill to avert US government shutdown – live updates
authors: Tom Ambrose, Shrai Popat, David Smith, Maya Yang, Sam Levin, Chris Stein, www.theguardian.com, tom-ambrose, shrai-popat, maya-yang
